Most often, optic nerve damage is caused by increased pressure in the eye.
Glaucoma is the second most common cause of blindness in the United States.
- In open-angle glaucoma, the increase in pressure is often small and slow.
Open-angle glaucoma is the most common type of glaucoma.
- The increased pressure pushes on the optic nerve.
- Open-angle glaucoma tends to run in families.
Your risk is higher if you have a parent or grandparent with open-angle glaucoma.
- Dilating eye drops and certain medicines may trigger an acute glaucoma attack.
- If you have had acute glaucoma in 1 eye, you are at risk for it in the second eye.

Causes include: - Drugs such as corticosteroids - Eye diseases such as uveitis (an infection of the middle layer of the eye) - Diseases such as diabetes - Eye injury Congenital glaucoma occurs in babies.
OPEN-ANGLE GLAUCOMA - Most people have no symptoms.
- Advanced glaucoma can lead to blindness.

- Cloudiness of the front of the eye - Enlargement of 1 eye or both eyes - Red eye - Sensitivity to light - Tearing SECONDARY GLAUCOMA - Symptoms are most often related to the underlying problem causing the glaucoma.
- Depending on the cause, symptoms may either be like open-angle glaucoma or angle-closure glaucoma.
Eye pressure can even be normal in some people with glaucoma.
- Photographs or laser scanning images of the inside of your eye (optic nerve imaging).
- Testing the clearness of your vision (visual acuity).
- You also may be given pills to lower pressure in the eye.
- Recently, new implants have been developed that can help treat glaucoma in people having cataract surgery.
- You may be given drops, pills, and medicine given through a vein (by IV) to lower your eye pressure.
